sense.name: the bottom surface of an area or place, often walked upon
sense.examples: The floors of this house are solid maple! John escorted Mary on to the dance floor. The ocean floor has fissures where black smokers exist. Her teenaged son always drops his clothes on the floor. Let's take a look at these floor plans. Betty doesn't like those floor lamps behind the couch.

sense.name: a functional level of a building
sense.examples: That elevator only goes as far as the eighteenth floor. The first three floors of this building are retail shops. They live on the fourth floor of an old brownstone apartment building. The firemen tried to keep the fire from spreading to the adjacent floors. He started on the ground floor of his company and worked up to vice-president. (figurative)

sense.name: a quantitative lower limit or boundary
sense.examples: The EU has established a new wage floor for manufacturing. Analysts are wondering whether the dollar has established a solid floor against the yen. Nixon's attempts to support prices with a price floor eventually led to stagflation.

sense.name: the occupants who dwell on a level of a building
sense.examples: Their floor at the dorm always has a keg party on Friday night. The whole floor complained about the lack of heat to the superintendent.

sense.name: the right to speak at an assembly or meeting
sense.examples: The senator from Alabama has the floor. The congressman yielded the floor to his colleague from Missouri. The chairman granted him the floor.

sense.name: a hall or room for legislative activity
sense.examples: There was a motion from the floor to adjourn the debate for the afternoon. Reporters will be watching the proceedings from the floor. A protester was removed from the floor before the president began her speech.

sense.name: a room where trading of financial securities takes place
sense.examples: A bomb went off on the trading floor of a large Wall Street securities firm today. Those seats on the floor of the NYSE cost over a million dollars a year.
